model.name: Las Vegas
model.description: Sin City. The Entertainment Capital of the World. Las Vegas goes by many names, but one thing is certain: The place grabs our attention with both its distinctive brand of glamour—extravagant-yet-chic hotels like the Wynn and the Cosmopolitan, nightclubs like Hakkasan and XS—and its sheer improbability, the fact that this monument of excess could spring up in the middle of a desert. One of the most popular tourist destinations in the world (the city attracted 40 million visitors in 2013), Las Vegas is no longer just a place to play the tables and catch a Celine Dion show—it's now a mecca for trade conventions, shopping, and fine dining. These days, Las Vegas is for the sinners and the saints.
model.seoName: Things To Do In Las Vegas – Attractions & Travel Guide
model.seoDescription: Plan your trip to Las Vegas with Condé Nast Traveler’s guide to the best hotels, restaurants, and things to do.
model.socialName: Vegas City Guide: Where to Eat, Stay, and Play
model.socialDescription: A complete guide to Vegas, compiled by Condé Nast Traveler editors.
model.dontMiss:
###See###

[#activity: /activities/53eae5ba976f8f2d44d58b73]|||
[The Bellagio Gallery of Fine Arts](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/las-vegas/bellagio-gallery-of-fine-art) is one of the best places in town to get your culture fix. Their current exhibit, “Picasso Creatures and Creativity,” features more than 45 of the master's works from 1930–1970. 
|||


###Explore###

[#activity: /activities/54948b7f287bf30b36b427f8]|||
The [Downtown Container Park](http://downtowncontainerpark.com/) is an outdoor mall made up of a collection of restaurants, bars, performance spaces and independent shops cleverly housed in and around a series of shipping containers. Activities for the whole family abound, including a kid-friendly interactive play area at the park’s center.
|||




###Explore###

[#hotel: /hotels/53db004adcd5888e145dc377]|||
Located on the fifth level floor at the rear of [The LINQ Hotel & Casino](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/las-vegas/the-linq-hotel-and-casino), [The Auto Collections](http://autocollections.com/index.cfm?tab=main&action=main) is at once a museum and show room (every car on display can be purchased). Check out more than 250 classic automobiles, featuring everything from the 1939 Chrysler Royal Sedan Johnny Carson drove to his senior prom to an assortment of 1960s muscle cars. 
|||


###Eat###


[#hotel: /hotels/54948202976b7507578b104c]|||
Michelin-star winning chef, Michael Mina, has opened his latest Vegas outpost, [Bardot Brasserie](http://aria.com/dining/restaurants/bardotbrasserie), at the [Aria Resort and Casino](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/aria--las-vegas). Come for classic French fare in a dining room that's reminiscent of archetypical Parisian brasseries.
|||

fields.name: Rebecca Frisch
fields.bio: Rebecca Frisch toddled into Sin City at the age of two and grew up watching casinos rise, fall and rise again. Since she didn’t have the neck strength to be a showgirl, she traded dreams of headlines for bylines and discovered the pen is, in fact, mightier than the sequined headdress.

stay.body:
[#image: /photos/53da91a26dec627b149f39f8]||||||

You already know how [luxuriously over-the-top](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/01/most-expensive-suites-vegas_slideshow_item0_1) your [favorite Las Vegas hotels](http://www.cntraveler.com/readers-choice-awards/united-states/best-hotels-las-vegas-photos) are. But—swank aside—these same hotels have some little-known facts and cool histories among them. From rooftop gardens that feed hotel restaurants, to personalized, artist-designed hotel logos, these fun facts will make you love your favorite Vegas hotels even more.





[#image: /photos/53da91a2dcd5888e145bd661]||||||
## [WYNN LAS VEGAS](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/encore-wynn-las-vegas-las-vegas-nevada)


The Wynn and its sister hotel, Encore, have almost 5,000 luxury hotel rooms, suites and villas between them—but they also share restaurants helmed by famous chefs, an 18-hole golf course, multiple pools, and even a beach club. Here are five cool facts about the Wynn you may not know:



1. **A Rare Chandelier from the Eiffel Tower Designer:** Installed at the Terrace Point Cafe entrance is a 1918 wood-and-glass chandelier designed by the famed Eiffel Tower architect, Gustav Eiffel. Steve Wynn, the eponymous hotelier behind the hotel, bought the rare piece at an auction at Christie’s Paris.







2. **One-of-a-Kind Designer Boutiques:** The Wynn’s retail Esplanade is filled with your standard luxury designer shops—but the Esplanade is also home to the only Alexander McQueen boutique in Las Vegas, and the second Manolo Blahnik store in the country.



3. **A $10,000 Cocktail That Comes With Cuff Links and a Necklace:** Encore’s nightclub, [XS](http://www.xslasvegas.com/), has crafted a libation, called Ono, that is truly excessive. The drink pairs Louis XIII’s elite Black Pearl Cognac with exclusive Piper-Heidsick’s Charlie champagne. Those who choose to drop $10,000 on the drink also receive an 18k gold necklace with a Tahitian black pearl hanging from a diamond beneath the gold XS logo. As well as a pair of Mont Blanc 18k gold cuff links. Phew.



4. **Jeff Koon’s Tulips structure:** Placed inside the Wynn Theater rotunda, this Jeff Koons sculpture is a bouquet of twisted balloon flowers, rendered in mirror-polished stainless steel with vivid, transparent color coating.







5.** Two Permanent Floral Installations:** The public art on display at the hotel is not limited to sculptures and paintings. Wynn recently unveiled two floral installations conceptualized by event designer Preston Bailey, in the shapes of a hot air balloon and an animated carousel.





[#image: /photos/53da91a2dcd5888e145bd65f]||||||
## [BELLAGIO](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/bellagio-las-vegas-las-vegas-nevada)


The 1,200 dancing fountains in front of the Bellagio are practically synonymous with Las Vegas itself. If you can see the Bellagio fountains from your hotel room, then you must have been upgraded. Yet there’s more than water to the always-elegant Bellagio.  







1. **Eco-Friendly Stretch Limousines: **Who knew? High-rollers care about their carbon footprint. Which is probably why the Bellagio now has six new stretch limousines powered by Compressed Natural Gas (CNG), which is one of the cleanest-burning alternative fuels available.



2.** Rooftop Garden:** Here’s one thing you can’t see at the Bellagio but you can certainly taste. Many of the herbs in the hotel’s restaurants are grown in the Bellagio’s rooftop garden.



3. **Olympic Performers:** Nearly a dozen of the 85 acrobats, divers, and synchronized swimmers in the “O” Cirque du Soleil show—which is performed in, on and above a 1.5 million-gallon pool—have participated in past Olympics. Some are even gold medalists.



4. **Controlling The Fountains: **If you’re a Pearl status member of [M Life](https://www.mlife.com/) (MGM Resorts’ loyalty program) you can choose two songs for the fountains to dance to, at a cost of $2,000. Or you can buy the $250,000 package from Hyde Bellagio, which gives you the largest bottle of champagne in the world (a 30-liter Ace of Spades) and a button that “controls” the fountains.



5. **Record-Setting Chocolate Fountain:** The chocolate fountain at the Jean-Phillippe Patisserie is nearly 27-feet tall and circulates an astonishing two tons of melted dark, milk and white chocolate at a rate of 120 quarts per minute. No wonder it holds the Guinness World Record for largest chocolate fountain.





[#image: /photos/53da91a26dec627b149f39fc]||||||
## [MANDARIN ORIENTAL](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/mandarin-oriental-las-vegas-las-vegas-nevada)


The Mandarin Oriental has nearly 400 guest rooms and suites spread throughout its 43 stories—but many of its best amenities can be experienced without having to book a room.



1. **A Distinct Logo:** Each Mandarin Oriental hotel commissions their own particular fan logo to reflect the individuality of the hotel and its location. The fan in Las Vegas is called “The Moment of Yuanfen” It was designed by Chinese-American artist Eric Jiaju Lee and is displayed in the Sky Lobby on the 23rd floor.







2. **A Proper Tea Lounge: **At the Mandarin Oriental Las Vegas, tea is served in the Sky Lobby, by staff trained in the art of Gong Fu Cha, a traditional Chinese tea ceremony. While guests sip on a variety of high grade Chinese teas, they can gaze out at the frenetic activity on The Strip. It's both calming and exhilarating.







3. **Mahjong Massage: **The hotel’s spa boasts a two-hour treatment inspired by the Chinese game of Mahjong that includes a welcoming foot ritual, body exfoliation, a massage with warm Jade stones, and an Oriental head massage. The $375 treatment concludes with actual Mahjong tiles to soothe and calm the body.







 4. **Jazz Sundays at the Mandarin Bar:** It’s quite unusual to hear live music in Vegas that doesn’t come from a tribute band or from one of the big celeb residencies on the Strip. But every Sunday night from 6 to 10pm, the contemporary Mandarin Bar features live jazz bands and a menu of specialty cocktails and light bites.



5.** The Twist Restaurant: **Chef Pierre Gagnaire chose the Mandarin Oriental to open his only restaurant in the U.S., [Twist](http://www.mandarinoriental.com/lasvegas/fine-dining/twist-by-pierre-gagnaire/). Serving edgy renditions of classical French cuisine, the restaurant nabbed one of Forbes five star awards last year.





[#image: /photos/53da91a26dec627b149f39fa]||||||
## [PALAZZO](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/palazzo-resort-hotel-casino-las-vegas-las-vegas-nevada)


Offering some of the largest standard accommodations on The Strip, The Palazzo expands on the “La Dolce Vita” lifestyle of its sister property, The Venetian.



1. **Chinese New Year Celebrations:** The Palazzo’s roots may be Italian but the resort transforms itself every Chinese New Year with an authentic dragon dance and a spectacular themed display. For the Year of the Horse, the Waterfall Atrium off the lobby is adorned with eight, hand-painted, sculpted horses, and one sculpted lamb, all surrounded by Chinese lanterns, bamboo towers, and intricate floral displays.



2. **One of the Largest Rooftop Solar-Energy Systems in the U.S.: **High above the crowded pool parties that draw visitors to the resort every summer is one of the largest rooftop solar-energy systems in the United States. This provides hot water for the swimming pools and the spa pools at the hotel’s Canyon Ranch Spa. Solar photovoltaic panels are also installed on the roof of a parking garage to generate electricity.



3. **Order Drinks Through the Slot Machine:** Instead of waiting for the busy cocktail server to come by your slot machine, you can now order your drink directly through the machine with the Drinks2U service. The option is available to members of the Club Grazie players’ club but once you’re in, you can select from beer, wine, mixed drinks, and in dire cases, water.



4. **Propose on a Gondola: **If you’ve dreamed of proposing to your significant other on a vacation in Italy but can’t quite make the trip, then consider proposing on a gondola in the Venetian and Palazzo’s Grand Canal. For $500, you’ll get a private ride in an authentic Venetian gondola, one dozen long-stemmed roses, a half-hour of professional photography, and the services of a personal event planner.



5.** Buddy V’s:** Buddy Valastro, the star of TLC’s “Cake Boss”, opened his first, full-fledged restaurant at The Palazzo last fall, serving hearty Italian-American entrees like eggplant parm, bucatini carbonara, and veal marsala. And we can’t forget dessert. The menu features Buddy’s XL lobster tail made with custard cream in a flaky pastry shell, Italian Birthday Cake, and Cannolis.

featuredStays.name: Wynn Las Vegas & Encore
featuredStays.description: Casino-resort the Wynn and its offshoot, Encore, have a list of five-star awards (Michelin, Forbes, Mobil, AAA) as long as the Strip itself. Sit down for a bite at any of the 10 on-site fine dining restaurants, watch aquatic acrobatic spectacle *Le Rêve,* and then retire to an upscale suite in the Tower or the Resort. And that’s only scratching the pearl-inlaid marble surface.
featuredStays.shortDescription: From Venetian-glass floors to white sycamore furnishings, this hotel oozes luxury.

featuredStays.name: Bellagio
featuredStays.description: An eight-and-a-half-acre manmade lake dominates the grounds of this casino-resort, which erupts into a dazzling choreographed fountain display every 15 to 30 minutes. But you have to go inside the Bellagio for the real glamour. The entryway features artist Dale Chihuly’s hand-blown glass sculpture, and the casino is home to a legendary high-stakes poker room. Take in Cirque du Soleil’s embedded show, *O,* and stay in the Five Diamond–winning comfort of the hotel’s Tuscan-style suites and villas.
featuredStays.shortDescription: The casino-resort's famous fountain offers the best free entertainment on the Strip.

featuredStays.name: The Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas
featuredStays.description: *Traveler* readers have called this newish spot, open since 2010, “fresh, fun, [and] sophisticated, yet not too Vegas.” The Cosmopolitan provides a welcome respite from the theme-iness of other hotels on the Strip. High-end rooms feature wraparound private terraces with skyline views. And it’s all about the nightlife here: Among your options are a three-story bar built inside a giant chandelier, and a hybrid nightclub/interactive show called *Rose. Rabbit. Lie.*
featuredStays.shortDescription: A modern hotel with quirky amenities like cigarette machines repurposed to dispense art pieces.

featuredStays.name: Mandarin Oriental, Las Vegas
featuredStays.description: Asian-style elegance is the order of the day at this resort, situated high above the street within the CityCenter complex, whose hotel, restaurant and spa are all five-starred. A two-floor spa includes 17 treatment rooms, a Chinese foot spa and a pool deck. The rooms, decorated in a contemporary Eastern aesthetic, are tricked out with temperature- and tech-controlling touch screens. Sip a cocktail at the Mandarin Bar, which also serves tapas and 23-story views of the surrounding city.
featuredStays.shortDescription: The Zen-like atmosphere here offers a serene escape from the hectic bustle of the Strip.

shop.hed: 10 Things You'll Only Find at The Shops at Crystals in Las Vegas
shop.dek: [The Shops at Crystals](http://cntraveler.com/shops/las-vegas/the-shops-at-crystals-citycenter), with its jagged and haphazard exterior edges, already stands out amongst the towering casinos on the Las Vegas Strip. But that's not the only thing that makes the luxury mall stand out: The 500,000-sq.ft. sleek shopper’s paradise, designed by architect Daniel Libeskind, houses the largest collection of “unique-to-market” stores ... and some pretty unique experiences too.

items.title: Visit an Art Gallery Inside Louis Vuitton
items.caption: At the largest Louis Vuitton store in North America, the store layout goes beyond glass cases of monogrammed bags, ready-to-wear, shoes and accessories. On display is “Akhob”, a permanent exhibition from light and space artist, James Turrell. It is his largest “ganzfeld effect” to date. Viewing the installation is only by appointment and only open to four people at a time. We do not recommend drinking before experiencing the effect.

items.title: Be a VIP in the Fitting Room at PRADA
items.caption: The distinctive pegboard exterior of PRADA’s largest store in the U.S. is a sight to behold to passersby on the Strip, but inside it is truly other level. The VIP fitting rooms have private entrances and couches lined with fox and chinchilla fur. A crocodile luggage set exclusive to Vegas is also for sale and one piece can cost as much as a car. This PRADA is also the only store in Vegas to carry runway collection pieces.

items.title: Admire The “Lucky Spot” Chandelier at Stella McCartney
items.caption: Decorated with 7,000 white Swarovski crystals, the dazzling horse chandelier, called “Lucky Spot”, was flown to the Vegas shop from its original home in Belsay Castle in Northern England. While at the store, pick up a special Stella McCartney t-shirt, designed exclusively for Las Vegas.

items.title: Indulge in a Facial from Sisley
items.caption: The first freestanding boutique from the French skincare line is offering signature radiance-enhancing and anti-aging treatments in a spa cabine area. Guests only need to purchase an item from Sisley to receive the facial.

items.title: Have a Bachelorette Party at Kiki de Montparnasse
items.caption: The lingerie shop’s “Girls Night In” package will host a champagne reception for the bride-to-be and her friends along with private fittings, jewelry consultations at the brand’s only Jewelry Bar location, and suggestions for what to take home from Pleasure Bar. This store also features a Portrait Booth for snapping sultry shots.

items.title: Buy a Briefcase for Your Wine Glasses at Lalique
items.caption: The only store for the crystal maker in Las Vegas is also its largest location in the U.S. Most everything created by Lalique can be found here, including Lalique 100 POINTS by James Suckling glassware collection and a limited edition leather briefcase designed by Salvatore Ferragamo to hold the glasses.

items.title: Snap Up Suitcases From Rimowa
items.caption: The Vegas outpost of the German luxury luggage maker carries an extensive array of suitcases in their 2,000-sq.ft. flagship boutique, from polycarbonate carry-ons to aluminum attaches and leather goods. Carry-ons start at $500 while larger suitcases can go for well over $1,000. You may need one to carry all your new items home.

items.title: Pick a Sporty Purse, or Phone, at Porsche Design
items.caption: There are no cars for sale at Porsche Design but rather, men’s and women’s accessories including handbags and suitcases, electronic products like a Porsche Design Blackberry, men’s fragrances and limited edition sunglasses and watches.

items.title: See the Other Celine in Las Vegas
items.caption: Celine Dion performs semi-regularly in Vegas but there’s another Celine who’s also worthy of a visit--the French fashion house, Céline, helmed by designer Phoebe Philo. The 4,200-square foot store carries ready-to-wear, handbag, shoe and accessory collections. And with a storefront that’s almost 100 feet long (the largest in Crystals), you won’t miss her, er, it.

items.title: Ogle Baubles from Harry Winston
items.caption: If you’re serious about purchasing some bling, you can take a closer look at Harry Winston’s handmade jewelry inside a private room which features a 30-foot cathedral ceiling. Pieces range from $4,000 to over a million dollars.

shop.hed: Shopping in Vegas: Where to Find Travel Essentials
shop.dek: Sometimes you just need a comb. Or contact lens solution. Or Spanx. Luckily, there are plenty of stores on and off the Strip where you won’t have to pay hotel gift shop prices.
shop.body:
[#image: /photos/5480d738860c74c1162c6b60]||||||

##McCarran International Airport   

__What you need:__ Make-up essentials, because you forgot to pack your cosmetics bag.  

__Where to find It:__ The Benefit Make-Up vending machine near the D Gates. Dressed up like a pink truck, the machine dispenses travel-sized make-up essentials from face wash to mascara, lipstick, and foundation. You can also hit up one of the three Sephora stores on the Strip.

##South Strip (Near resorts like Mandalay, MGM Grand, New York, New York)   

__What you need:__ A phone charger, since your battery is at one percent and you just arrived in Vegas.  

__Where to find it:__ The Best Buy vending machine at the MGM Grand for phone chargers, cameras, headphones, and more. 
 
##Center Strip (Caesars Palace, Bellagio CityCenter, Planet Hollywood)  

__What you need:__ Basic toiletries like contact lens solution, comb, and/or deodorant at regular   
drugstore prices.   

__Where to find it:__ The two-story Walgreens next to Planet Hollywood. Stock up on bottled water, Advil, and lip balm while you’re there too. 

##North Strip (Wynn, Venetian, Trump, SLS)  

__What you need:__ Spanx, to better fit into your evening wear.  

__Where to find it:__ The new Spanx store at the Fashion Show Mall. And yes, they sell men’s Spanx too. 

##Downtown Las Vegas  

__What you need:__ New clothes that won’t cut into your partying budget.  

__Where to find it:__ The Las Vegas North Premium Outlets, where you can browse the racks at Theory, BCBG, Vince, Diane Von Furstenberg, and Salvatore Ferragamo.

##Off the Strip (Red Rock, Green Valley Ranch, JW Marriott)  

__What you need:__ Chocolate-covered potato chips and other essential grocery items.  

__Where to find it:__ Trader Joe’s just opened at Downtown Summerlin, which also features a Nordstrom Rack, a Wolfgang Puck Bar & Grill, and a Regal movie theater.

shop.hed: Where To Find Unique Goods in a Souvenir Town
shop.dek: Even the bleary-eyed visitors to Vegas are keen to point out that most of the merchandise for sale in the stores can be bought “back home” at other malls. This is, for the most part, very true but several high-end retailers in Sin City have dropped a few hidden gems amongst the brand name offerings and wacky memorabilia stores. Here are the pieces visitors would be hard-pressed to find back home.
shop.seoDescription: Conde Nast Traveler reveals where to find one-of-kind items in a town cluttered with souvenir shops and designer stores.
shop.socialDescription: Conde Nast Traveler reveals where to find one-of-kind items in a town cluttered with souvenir shops and designer stores.

items.title: [MULBERRY](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/las-vegas/mulberry-las-vegas) AT THE FORUM SHOPS AT CAESARS PALACE
items.caption: The British handbag line celebrated the opening of its first store in August with a capsule collection of limited edition, embellished pieces like the Clemmie, a black suede clutch studded with dozens of gunmetal rivets. This is a piece you can only buy in Las Vegas.

items.title: [HUBLOT](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/las-vegas/hulbot-las-vegas-the-forum-shops-at-caesars-palace) BIG BANG FERRARI LAS VEGAS EDITION AT THE FORUM SHOPS
items.caption: Watchmakers Hublot partnered up with Ferrari to create this exclusive-to-Vegas timepiece. The $27,500 watch features a 45mm Unico Big Bang case and two interchangeable straps, each made with genuine Ferrari leather.

items.title: ASTLEY CLARKE JEWELRY AT [FRED SEGAL](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/las-vegas/fred-segal-jewels-sls-las-vegas) JEWELS, SLS LAS VEGAS
items.caption: The London-based jewelry line counts Alexa Chung and Miranda Kerr as fans, but their delicate bracelets, necklaces and rings, which feature colored gemstones, can usually only be bought online or in the UK. But now Fred Segal Jewels at the SLS Las Vegas is one of the few stores that carry the line in the U.S.

items.title: [GIVENCHY](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/las-vegas/givenchy-at-the-wynn-las-vegas) AT THE WYNN LAS VEGAS
items.caption: Located in the Wynn’s high-end Esplanade, this is the only store from the French haute couture clothier in the entire United States. Both men’s and women’s ready-to-wear lines are offered as well as luxury bags and accessories.

items.title: CHRISTIAN DIOR PYTHON PURSE AT [CRYSTALS AT CITYCENTER](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/las-vegas/the-shops-at-crystals-citycenter)
items.caption: Only a very small handful of Dior stores carry this brightly colored, blue-shaded python skin purse, but you can find it at The Shops at Crystals – the luxury shopping mall at CityCenter. The exclusive purse retails for $7,100.

items.title: RICHARD MILLE TOURBILLON RM1901 NATALIE PORTMAN AT CRYSTALS
items.caption: One of only 20 timepieces designed and created by Richard Mille and Natalie Portman can be found at [The Shops at Crystals](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/las-vegas/the-shops-at-crystals-citycenter). The exquisite spider watch is set with baguette rubies, totalling 16.1 carats and $1.5 million.

items.title: [BAUMAN RARE BOOKS](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/las-vegas/baumann-rare-books-the-venetian) AT THE PALAZZO
items.caption: Eager to make a more meaningful purchase? Head over to this 2,300-square-foot rare books haven inside The Grand Canal Shoppes at The Venetian to (carefully) peruse first editions and rare books, alongside musical compositions, letters, and photography.

items.title: [RENT THE RUNWAY](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/las-vegas/rent-the-runway-cosmopolitan-of-las-vegas) AT THE COSMOPOLITAN
items.caption: Technically, you can’t take these dresses home, but this is the only showroom for the popular dress rental app near the West Coast. Simply browse the dresses you like, rent it for the night, and return it the next day. They even do the dry-cleaning.

items.title: [STITCHED](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/las-vegas/stitched-cosmopolitan-of-las-vegas) AT THE COSMOPOLITAN
items.caption: Women have no shortage of places to buy new outfits for nights out on the Strip, but thanks to Stitched, now gentlemen can pick up a few bespoke and custom-tailored items during their trip. Measuring only by appointment.

items.title: [DISNEY STORE](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/las-vegas/disney-store-las-vegas-fashion-show-mall) LAS VEGAS
items.caption: This one is for the obsessive Disney Collectors out there. The Disney Store inside The Fashion Show Mall features exclusive Vegas items including a Minnie Mouse plush doll dressed up as a Vegas showgirl and a Stitch plush doll dressed in a white, rhinestone-studded Elvis get up.

fields.name: Juliana Shallcross
fields.shortBio: Juliana is a digital contributor to *Condé Nast Traveler*.
fields.bio: Juliana Shallcross was the managing editor of three daily travel sites-- [HotelChatter.com](http://hotelchatter.com/), [Jaunted.com](http://jaunted.com/) and [VegasChatter.com](http://vegaschatter.com/)--for over ten years. Now, she's keeping tabs on the ever-changing hotel landscape for *Condé Nast Traveler*. Aside from maintaing a healthy (most of the time) obsession with hotels, she's also chronicling cool places to take the kids at her own site, [TripsandGiggles.com](http://tripsandgiggles.com/). She's currently based in Los Angeles. Her favorite hotel amenities are fluffy pillows and free WiFi.

cheatSheet.dek: If there was ever a place to feel like a VIP, it's Vegas. We're talking the old-school, Deano-and-Frank kind of treatment, where extravagance is a god-given right.

items.hed: Mandarin Bar (inside the Mandarin Oriental, Las Vegas)
items.dek: Enjoy inventive cocktails and an impressive view at this bar perched 23 floors above the Strip.
The only spot in Vegas zoned for fireworks is this nightclub on the roof at The Cromwell Hotel.
The quintessential Las Vegas high-end art destination hosts rotating exhibits.
Gold-embossed crocodile VIP booths. $10,000 cocktails. The best scene in town.
A private, indulgent 22-course tasting menu where the foie gras comes as a whole lobe.
Take laps around the Las Vegas Motor Speedway in a Ferrari—it's a speed demon's fantasy realized.

cheatSheet.dek: The 'other' side of Vegas: the best destinations and activities found off the strip.

items.dek: Shipping containers-turned-boutiques, offering an ever-changing mix of clothing, art, and more.
This collection of 150 neon signs, dating from the 1930s, is the largest in the world.
You're likely to find artists chatting alongside office types at this Arts District watering hole.
You'll find custom cocktails and smoked-to-order single malts at this tiny, members-only spot.
This indie-brand stocked boutique is the antidote to luxury shopping on the Strip.
A well-appointed cocktail bar that's less Calvin Harris, more Calvin Coolidge.

cheatSheet.dek: Casinos? What casinos? For many, the  Vegas pool parties—with their luxury cabanas and free-flowing champagne—are reason enough to visit.

items.hed: Garden of the Gods Pool Oasis
items.dek: There’s a place for everyone—adults and kids alike— at this seven pool 'oasis' in Caesar's Palace.
Get to this 1,200 square-foot pool before 10 a.m. and have the place almost entirely to yourself.
A perpetual scene, go here less to take a dip and more to watch the young and beautiful dance.
Seek solace at the Mandarin Oriental’s pool, an unusually calm and quiet spot in this crazy city.
Its location on the 4th floor of the Venetian adds an air of tranquility to this 5-acre facility.
Enjoy three tiers of pools and two infinity hot tubs at this only-in-Vegas-style party.

fields.title: caesars las vegas pool
fields.caption: Obviously, not all Vegas pools are fit for families, but there’s a place for everyone at Caesars Palace’s five-acre **[Garden of the Gods Pool Oasis](http://www.caesarspalace.com/things-to-do/garden-of-the-gods-pool-oasis.html)**, whose seven pools—one adults-only—have names and decor inspired by Roman gods (702-731-7280; cover, $10–$20).

related.hed: Where to Dine With Locals in Las Vegas
related.dek: Las Vegas's sinful reputation is so well ingrained that the mere mention of the city conjures images of shining neon and ringing slots. But if you head away from the glitz of the Strip, you’ll find a city of 2 million coming into its own with whimsical boutiques, destination bars, and brilliant restaurants where locals nibble on Mount Fuji-inspired cakes or slurp down stunning Thai curries at 2 a.m.
related.seoTitle: Where to Dine With Locals in Las Vegas
related.seoDescription: Get off the Strip and find your way to Downtown gems, secret cocktail bars, and a sushi temple where the fish are straight out of Tokyo.
related.socialTitle: Where to Dine With Locals in Las Vegas
related.socialDescription: Get off the Strip and find your way to Downtown gems, secret cocktail bars, and a sushi temple where the fish are straight out of Tokyo.

items.title: [Carson Kitchen](https://cnt.conde.io/restaurants/las-vegas/carson-kitchen)
items.caption:
Housed in a former motel, this Downtown gastropub is the latest local venue from celebrity chef Kerry Simon. The restaurant, a collaboration with Zappos founder Tony Hsieh’s Downtown Project investment company, walks the line between hip and homey with inventive comfort food, communal tables, and cocktails worth a visit all on their own. (The Towns End packs a whiskey wallop balanced with Fernet Vittone, Amaro del Sole and two kinds of bitters.) Grab a seat at the chef’s counter alongside local movers and shakers and watch the kitchen turn out plates of bacon jam and black rice oxtail risotto.  

*Distance from the Strip: 4 miles*

items.title: [Japanese Cuisine by Omae](https://cnt.conde.io/restaurants/las-vegas/japanese-cuisine-by-omae)
items.caption:
A bland strip mall isn’t where you’d expect to find superb Japanese cooking, but that’s where chef Takeshi Omae—who earned a Michelin star at Morimoto XEX in Tokyo—placed his eponymous eatery last summer, alongside a pool hall and a Super Cuts. Omae himself is in the kitchen here, crafting menus full of ambitious, original dishes like sweet shrimp tartare with tomato sorbet and celeriac puree. Reserve one of the four tables for dinner before it becomes impossible to nab a seat, or stop by for lunch when three courses—including mains like tonkatsu pork with black curry or hamburg steak with foie gras—go for just $20. 

*Distance from the Strip: 3 miles*

items.title: [Velveteen Rabbit](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/las-vegas/velveteen-rabbit)
items.caption:
Sisters Christina and Pam Dylag spent two years developing this Arts District watering hole, which has become a local staple where you’ll now find musicians and artists chatting alongside lawyers and office workers. The “elixirs” menu features inventive cocktails using house-made ingredients, including chai syrup, tamarind soda, and roasted beet and sage vermouth. Beer drinkers will also be plenty happy, with local breweries sharing room with regional heavyweights like Ballast Point and Uinta. Early evenings bring a sip-and-savor crowd to the Victorian-style couches and outdoor patio, while DJs keep the party going into the wee hours. 

*Distance from the Strip: 3 miles*

items.title: [Kabuto](https://cnt.conde.io/restaurants/las-vegas/kabuto)
items.caption:
Here’s what you *won’t* find at this Chinatown restaurant: maki rolls, shrimp tempura, and definitely no cream cheese. Instead, chefs assemble pristine nigiri, slicing hunks of unusual species like gizzard shad and hairtail that are imported regularly from Japan and beyond. The warmly lit, minimalist space is focused around the wooden sushi bar; reserve a seat there at least a week out so you can watch the ritual unfold.

*Distance from the Strip: 3 miles*

items.title: [365 Tokyo](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/las-vegas/365-tokyo)
items.caption:
From the outside, this petite cocktail bar is an odd glass box jutting from the front of Downtown’s Inspire building, but this members-only boite is actually a Japanese-inspired cocktail haven. (Despite the exclusivity, there’s a way to get in: Ask about reservations around Inspire or its sister venues Scullery and Downtown Cocktail Room). Award-winning bartender Seong Ha Lee runs the show, slinging custom cocktails, smoked-to-order single malts (over ice spheres, if you prefer), liquid nitrogen-frozen Guinness, and siphon-charged sippers carbonated before your eyes.

*Distance from the Strip: 4 miles*

items.title: [DW Bistro](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/las-vegas/dw-bistro)
items.caption:
It’s worth the wait for brunch at this longtime local favorite, where the menu nods to Jamaican and Southwestern flavors—and if you do have to wait, you might see co-owner Bryce Krausman at the door welcoming guests and chatting up regulars. When you finally snag a table, sate your hunger with a basket of warm blueberry and white chocolate scones and a Bloody Mary, generously garnished with olives, a pickle and a few strips of jalapeño bacon. Together they’re the perfect introduction to a meal of jerk fried chicken and waffles, New Mexican-style slow-cooked pork, or chilaquiles topped with chicken, eggs and avocado tomatillo sauce. 

*Distance from the Strip: 10 miles*

items.title: [Sweets Raku](https://cnt.conde.io/restaurants/las-vegas/sweets-raku)
items.caption:
Your first treat at this Chinatown sweet shop is the menu itself, a list of the day’s dessert creations printed onto a sheet of edible paper and served with a dollop of fruit sauce. You’ll want the three-course tasting, a showcase of chef Mio Ogasawara’s inventive French/Japanese meticulously crafted pastries, including the Mt. Fuji, a boulder-like cake made from ribbons of chestnut cream, and Stella, a sculptural interpretation of strawberry tiramisu. 

*Distance from the Strip: 3 miles*

items.title: [Chada Thai & Wine](https://cnt.conde.io/restaurants/las-vegas/chada-thai-and-wine)
items.caption:
In another city, Chada might be overrun with diners clamoring for its balanced Thai cooking with a slight southern lean. But in Vegas, two years after it started serving refined fare that goes well beyond the ubiquitous curries and noodles, this restaurant still feels under the radar. In-the-know locals gush over chef and sommelier Bank Atcharawan’s affordable, Riesling-heavy wine list, as well as dishes like crab curry, fried Cornish game hen with garlic and the umami-packing pad hed, stir fried shiitake and shimenji mushrooms with Brussels sprouts and lotus root. And since this is Vegas, the full menu is served until 3 a.m. nightly. 

*Distance from the Strip: 4 miles*

items.title: [Chocolate & Spice Bakery](https://cnt.conde.io/restaurants/las-vegas/chocolate-and-spice-bakery)
items.caption:
After more than a decade as executive pastry chef at Charlie Palmer’s Aureole, Megan Romano struck out on her own in 2012, launching this west-side cafe where the scent of fresh-baked goodies fills the air and the pastry case is perpetually stocked with dainty chocolates and luscious cakes. Grab a plate of creme brûlée French toast or a roasted veggie panini and settle into an oversized chair in the bright, inviting interior. Just make sure you leave room for brownie parfait or banana cream pie for dessert. 

*Distance from the Strip: 6.5 miles*

fields.name: Sarah Feldberg
fields.shortBio: Sarah Feldberg is a writer and editor based in San Francisco and Las Vegas.
fields.bio: Sarah Feldberg is a writer and editor based in San Francisco and Las Vegas. The former editor-in-chief of *Las Vegas Weekly* magazine, she travels as much as possible, makes a mean lasagna and practices her Spanish with anyone who will listen. It gets better with two beers, worse with three.

related.hed: 8 Ways To Dine Family Style in Vegas
related.dek: In a city filled with the with everything from gourmet eateries to 24-hour buffets, it's no surprise that there a plenty of options for the whole family. Check out these 8 Vegas spots that are great for the kids.

items.title: [The Buffet at Bellagio, Bellagio](www.bellagio.com)
items.caption: Any trip to a buffet will be exciting for the kids. Unfortunately, the same isn't always true for the parents. Make sure everyone’s happy by visiting one of the best all-you-can-eat destinations on the Strip. The children will likely skip over the impressive array of gourmet delicacies on offer, but that just leave more caviar, crab legs and sushi for you.

items.title: [800 Degrees, Monte Carlo](www.montecarlo.com)
items.caption: Dining with a healthy helping of creativity? Yes, please. Fire the whole family's imaginations at this create-your-own pizzeria where what’s on the menu is only limited by personal taste. Guests choose their own sauce, proteins, cheese and veggies, then watch as their culinary masterpiece comes to life.

items.title: [Giada, The Cromwell](www.caesars.com/cromwell)
items.caption: Take the kids to Food Network star Giada de Laurentiis's highly lauded new restaurant, Giada. They will love the open-air views of the iconic Strip and of the Bellagio’s famed fountains.  Stop in for breakfast (try the excellent strawberry polenta waffle) or lunch (the lemon pesto grilled cheese is delicious), rather than dinner, for a more laid back casual experience that is a bit easier on the wallet, too.

items.title: [Du-par’s, Golden Gate](www.du-pars.com)
items.caption: You'd be hard pressed to find a greater crowd pleaser than a stack of fresh hot cakes. The pancakes made daily at this downtown Vegas diner are so tasty they’ve won awards so they’re sure to win over appetites of all ages, too.

items.title: [Gordon Ramsay BurGR, Planet Hollywood](www.planethollywoodresort.com)
items.caption: Burgers and fries will always be a hit, and the fresh and delicious options on offer at Gordon Ramsay's BurGR in Planet Hollywood are no exception.  Order an American Burger to get your classic fix or the Hell's Kitchen Burger for something a little more nouveau.

items.title: [Fulton Street Food Hall, Harrah’s](www.harrahslasvegas.com)
items.caption: With a cafeteria-style layout, school age children will feel right at home at this unique mashup of a cafe and food court. Walk-up stations offer pizzas, salads and sandwiches as well as fresh-made sushi and steaming bowls of noodles.

items.title: [Tournament of Kings, Excalibur](www.excalibur.com)
items.caption: Cheer on jousting knights as you allow the kids to get medieval and dine with their hands at the Strip’s only dinner show. A standard menu includes Cornish Game Hen, potatoes, broccoli and a roll. Vegetarian, vegan, kosher, gluten- and dairy free requests can be accommodated with notice.
items.credit: Erik Kabik for MGM Resorts International

items.title: [Veranda, Four Seasons](www.fourseasons.com/lasvegas)
items.caption: The friendly staff will put you at ease with their attentiveness to even the youngest of patrons while the menu offers a selection of old favorites like pizza and ravioli sure to please even the pickiest of eaters. Bonus points for not even blinking at requests for hot dogs at breakfast.

related.socialTitle: 8 Ways To Dine Family Style in Vegas
related.socialDescription: Bright lights. Big city. Hungry kiddies. Here are the best places to eat with the kids in Sin City.
related.seoDescription: Conde Nast Traveler identifies the 8 best restaurants to dine with family in Las Vegas.

fields.name: Rebecca Frisch
fields.bio: Rebecca Frisch toddled into Sin City at the age of two and grew up watching casinos rise, fall and rise again. Since she didn’t have the neck strength to be a showgirl, she traded dreams of headlines for bylines and discovered the pen is, in fact, mightier than the sequined headdress.

related.hed: The Mob Museum Welcomes FIFA to its Halls
related.dek: The Las Vegas museum debuts a new exhibit, The 'Beautiful Games' Turns Ugly, on September 1.
related.body:
[#image: /photos/55bbaee86966466e2ce304b2]||||||





Just how corrupt is FIFA, the governing body of the world's most popular sport? Enough that it's getting its own permanent spot at a museum dedicated to the world of organized crime, jostling for exhibition space with John Gotti's leisure suit and a .38 from the St. Valentine's Day Massacre. In September, Las Vegas's Mob Museum will open __[The 'Beautiful Game' Turns Ugly,](http://themobmuseum.org/press_releases/the-beautiful-game-turns-ugly-new-mob-museum-display-explores-corruption-of-fifa/)__ an exhibit that will wade into the sludge pit of corruption that has plagued the Fédération Internationale de Football Association for decades.

Why the not-so-honorable distinction? In a way, FIFA operates much like a global, billion-dollar crime family: no government oversite, no taxes paid, and decades of widespread venality that led to a multinational investigation earlier this year. A pair of inquiries spearheaded by justice departments in the U.S. and Switzerland led to a scene straight out of a mob movie—a raid on FIFA's Zurich headquarters in which 14 of the organization's officials were arrested. Bribes for broadcasting rights in the neighborhood of $150 million? Votes bought to ensure World Cup hosting rights? Money laundering? Fraud? Fixing games? FIFA has been accused of it all. 

The Mob Museum's exhibition will examine FIFA's numerous sins piece by piece, using photos, newspaper clippings, and other ephemera to delve into the complicated story. Ex-FIFA president Sepp Blatter (who resigned his post in June) may be in a permanent time-out, but soccer fans will have plenty to chew on until the next World Cup rolls around.

*The 'Beautiful Game' Turns Ugly opens September 1 at the Mob Museum in Las Vegas, NV.*

fields.name: Jenna Scherer
fields.shortBio: Jenna is a Brooklyn-based writer, editor, and rouser of rabble.
fields.bio: Jenna is a writer, editor, and pop-culture critic whose work has appeared in *Rolling Stone, Hemispheres Magazine,* Made Man, *The Boston Herald,* Time Out Boston, and The Watershed Post. Most recently, she was associate editor at *Time Out New York.* Journalistic research has taken her from the catwalks of haunted theaters in Boston to helicopters over Manhattan. When traveling, she can usually be found climbing to the tops of very tall things. She lives in Brooklyn.

related.hed: 10 Things You'll Only Find at The Shops at Crystals in Las Vegas
related.dek: [The Shops at Crystals](http://cntraveler.com/shops/las-vegas/the-shops-at-crystals-citycenter), with its jagged and haphazard exterior edges, already stands out amongst the towering casinos on the Las Vegas Strip. But that's not the only thing that makes the luxury mall stand out: The 500,000-sq.ft. sleek shopper’s paradise, designed by architect Daniel Libeskind, houses the largest collection of “unique-to-market” stores ... and some pretty unique experiences too.

items.title: Visit an Art Gallery Inside Louis Vuitton
items.caption: At the largest Louis Vuitton store in North America, the store layout goes beyond glass cases of monogrammed bags, ready-to-wear, shoes and accessories. On display is “Akhob”, a permanent exhibition from light and space artist, James Turrell. It is his largest “ganzfeld effect” to date. Viewing the installation is only by appointment and only open to four people at a time. We do not recommend drinking before experiencing the effect.

items.title: Be a VIP in the Fitting Room at PRADA
items.caption: The distinctive pegboard exterior of PRADA’s largest store in the U.S. is a sight to behold to passersby on the Strip, but inside it is truly other level. The VIP fitting rooms have private entrances and couches lined with fox and chinchilla fur. A crocodile luggage set exclusive to Vegas is also for sale and one piece can cost as much as a car. This PRADA is also the only store in Vegas to carry runway collection pieces.

items.title: Admire The “Lucky Spot” Chandelier at Stella McCartney
items.caption: Decorated with 7,000 white Swarovski crystals, the dazzling horse chandelier, called “Lucky Spot”, was flown to the Vegas shop from its original home in Belsay Castle in Northern England. While at the store, pick up a special Stella McCartney t-shirt, designed exclusively for Las Vegas.

items.title: Indulge in a Facial from Sisley
items.caption: The first freestanding boutique from the French skincare line is offering signature radiance-enhancing and anti-aging treatments in a spa cabine area. Guests only need to purchase an item from Sisley to receive the facial.

items.title: Have a Bachelorette Party at Kiki de Montparnasse
items.caption: The lingerie shop’s “Girls Night In” package will host a champagne reception for the bride-to-be and her friends along with private fittings, jewelry consultations at the brand’s only Jewelry Bar location, and suggestions for what to take home from Pleasure Bar. This store also features a Portrait Booth for snapping sultry shots.

items.title: Buy a Briefcase for Your Wine Glasses at Lalique
items.caption: The only store for the crystal maker in Las Vegas is also its largest location in the U.S. Most everything created by Lalique can be found here, including Lalique 100 POINTS by James Suckling glassware collection and a limited edition leather briefcase designed by Salvatore Ferragamo to hold the glasses.

items.title: Snap Up Suitcases From Rimowa
items.caption: The Vegas outpost of the German luxury luggage maker carries an extensive array of suitcases in their 2,000-sq.ft. flagship boutique, from polycarbonate carry-ons to aluminum attaches and leather goods. Carry-ons start at $500 while larger suitcases can go for well over $1,000. You may need one to carry all your new items home.

items.title: Pick a Sporty Purse, or Phone, at Porsche Design
items.caption: There are no cars for sale at Porsche Design but rather, men’s and women’s accessories including handbags and suitcases, electronic products like a Porsche Design Blackberry, men’s fragrances and limited edition sunglasses and watches.

items.title: See the Other Celine in Las Vegas
items.caption: Celine Dion performs semi-regularly in Vegas but there’s another Celine who’s also worthy of a visit--the French fashion house, Céline, helmed by designer Phoebe Philo. The 4,200-square foot store carries ready-to-wear, handbag, shoe and accessory collections. And with a storefront that’s almost 100 feet long (the largest in Crystals), you won’t miss her, er, it.

items.title: Ogle Baubles from Harry Winston
items.caption: If you’re serious about purchasing some bling, you can take a closer look at Harry Winston’s handmade jewelry inside a private room which features a 30-foot cathedral ceiling. Pieces range from $4,000 to over a million dollars.

eat.body:
[#image: /photos/53da9a80dcd5888e145bfab3]||||||

_ Welcome to Elevator Pitch, in which we invite the chefs, owners and other boldfaced names behind some of the country’s most exciting new restaurants to tell us why their ventures are worthy of our dining dollars._



Today we’re headed to Vegas, where the strip’s newest interactive dinner-theater mashup has taken up residence at the Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas. With its tap-dancing twins, aerialists and backlit rendering of Hieronymus Bosch’s “Garden of Earthly Delights,” [Rose.Rabbit.Lie.](http://roserabbitlie.com)’s sensory thrills aren’t limited to the kitchen. But executive chef Wesley Holton’s upgraded classics still deserve their own star turn. Holton tells us about what to eat while enjoying the spot’s quirky vaudevillian entertainment.







"Rose. Rabbit. Lie. offers a totally different experience from anything else currently on the Strip. In the kitchen, we’re taking inspiration from classics and updating them for modern times—think beef Wellington and oysters Rockefeller. Also inspired by classics, our cocktails are perfect for enjoying with dinner or while watching Vegas Nocturne, the entertainment offered in three cantos a night with a variety of wild acts, and also throughout the venue at unexpected moments. You can have caviar and a giant platter of king crab on your table and look up to see twin tap dancers dancing on the bar.”



 



**More on Las Vegas:**







[Cool Facts About Las Vegas’s Top Hotels](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/01/cool-facts-las-vegas-top-hotels)







[The Most Expensive Suites at Vegas’s Top Hotels](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/01/most-expensive-suites-vegas_slideshow_item0_1)







[What Not to Do in Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/12/what-not-to-do-in-las-vegas_slideshow_item0_1)

They will love the open-air views of the iconic Strip and of the Bellagio’s famed fountains.  Stop in for breakfast (try the excellent strawberry polenta waffle) or lunch (the lemon pesto grilled cheese is delicious), rather than dinner, for a more laid back casual experience that is a bit easier on the wallet, too.

items.title: [Du-par’s, Golden Gate](www.du-pars.com)
items.caption: You'd be hard pressed to find a greater crowd pleaser than a stack of fresh hot cakes. The pancakes made daily at this downtown Vegas diner are so tasty they’ve won awards so they’re sure to win over appetites of all ages, too.

items.title: [Gordon Ramsay BurGR, Planet Hollywood](www.planethollywoodresort.com)
items.caption: Burgers and fries will always be a hit, and the fresh and delicious options on offer at Gordon Ramsay's BurGR in Planet Hollywood are no exception.  Order an American Burger to get your classic fix or the Hell's Kitchen Burger for something a little more nouveau.

items.title: [Fulton Street Food Hall, Harrah’s](www.harrahslasvegas.com)
items.caption: With a cafeteria-style layout, school age children will feel right at home at this unique mashup of a cafe and food court. Walk-up stations offer pizzas, salads and sandwiches as well as fresh-made sushi and steaming bowls of noodles.

items.title: [Tournament of Kings, Excalibur](www.excalibur.com)
items.caption: Cheer on jousting knights as you allow the kids to get medieval and dine with their hands at the Strip’s only dinner show. A standard menu includes Cornish Game Hen, potatoes, broccoli and a roll. Vegetarian, vegan, kosher, gluten- and dairy free requests can be accommodated with notice.
items.credit: Erik Kabik for MGM Resorts International

items.title: [Veranda, Four Seasons](www.fourseasons.com/lasvegas)
items.caption: The friendly staff will put you at ease with their attentiveness to even the youngest of patrons while the menu offers a selection of old favorites like pizza and ravioli sure to please even the pickiest of eaters. Bonus points for not even blinking at requests for hot dogs at breakfast.

eat.socialTitle: 8 Ways To Dine Family Style in Vegas
eat.socialDescription: Bright lights. Big city. Hungry kiddies. Here are the best places to eat with the kids in Sin City.
eat.seoDescription: Conde Nast Traveler identifies the 8 best restaurants to dine with family in Las Vegas.

fields.name: Rebecca Frisch
fields.bio: Rebecca Frisch toddled into Sin City at the age of two and grew up watching casinos rise, fall and rise again. Since she didn’t have the neck strength to be a showgirl, she traded dreams of headlines for bylines and discovered the pen is, in fact, mightier than the sequined headdress.

eat.body:
[#image: /photos/53e2e3e4dddaa35c30f62b59]||||||

 


##### _WHERE TO EAT_










 Known for poker, parties, and pools, Vegas is also an eater’s hub. Here, a restaurant for every budget.






#####



 **$**


You won’t see flashing lights or tacky decor at the izakaya [Aburiya Raku](http://www.raku-grill.com/), an off-Strip locals’ joint. Instead, there are tasteful dishes like the foie gras and egg custard soup and cold green tea soba with poached egg (5030 W. Spring Mountain Rd.; 702-367-3511; small plates from $3).



 

[#image: /photos/53e2e3e4c2d3f39d36107feb]||||||
##### $$


[China Poblano](http://www.chinapoblano.com/), which serves shareable modern Mexican and Chinese cuisine, has steamed barbecue pork buns that are to die for, as are the inventive tacos: The Silencio comes with duck tongue and fresh lychee (The Cosmopolitan; 702-698-7900; small plates from $5).



 


##### $$$


A perk of dining at [Scarpetta](http://scottconant.com/restaurants/scarpetta/las-vegas): front-row seats to the Bellagio fountains light show. The perfectly executed Italian food includes roast diver scallops with watermelon radish and pea foam, and house-made king crab and squid fettuccine (The Cosmopolitan; 702-698-7960; entrées from $25).







 



 



 



Photos from top: Jeff Green, Kat Bryant

pinterest.hed: Restaurateur Jenna Morton's Guide to Las Vegas
pinterest.dek: As a restaurateur who runs three buzzy Las Vegas dining spots—La Cave, La Comida, and Crush—Jenna Morton knows exactly how to spend a night on the town.
pinterest.body:
[#image: /photos/546d2bf42a3d21fa285c8610]||||||


“Las Vegas’s Downtown is booming, and La Comida—the Mexican restaurant my husband, Michael, and I opened there last year—is where I start the evening with a shot or two of Casamigos Anejo. After, barhop down Fremont Street. Begin with La Comida’s neighbor Commonwealth, then hit Beauty Bar, The Griffin, Downtown Cocktail Room ('DCR' to locals), and Park on Fremont. Make a slight detour between saloons to the Instagram-ready [Neon Boneyard](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-06-11/las-vegas-neon-museum), where iconic Las Vegas signs go to retire (book a night tour in advance).

The next day, cleanse yourself with a hike in the Springs Preserve—Vegas’s answer to [Central Park](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-07-17/vintage-photos-of-central-park-nyc), which has easy trails in the center
of town—or Red Rock Canyon, one of the best climbing destinations in the world and just a 20-minute drive from the Strip. The reward for reaching the top of Turtlehead Peak is a spectacular view of the entire valley.”


[#article: /articles/546d1aa415fa044b14f2de00]||||||

fields.name: Alice Newell-Hanson
fields.shortBio: Alice Newell-Hanson is an assistant editor at Condé Nast Traveler.

pinterest.body:
[#image: /photos/53d9c64fdcd5888e1459c51c]||||||

Vegas is supposed to have something for everyone. I was doubtful of the truth in that remark, but then, I found the [Neon Museum](http://www.neonmuseum.org/), a few miles north of the strip. You can barely peek through the fence at the wonders inside—if you want a look at the outrageous color and typography that is vintage Vegas neon, you’ll have to take a tour.



And it’s totally worth it. The peeling paint and broken light bulbs and sharp metal edges of the giant neon signs make for [amazing photos](http://www.nerdseyeview.com/blog/2009/10/21/in-the-neon-boneyard/). But the guides are great storytellers too. Under the hot Nevada sunshine (bring a hat, a bottle of water, and wear sunscreen), I heard tales of mobsters and musicians and life in a city without clocks. The crazy thing? I now have a reason to go back to Vegas. That's unexpected.

pinterest.dek: Bikinis! Bellinis! Kardashians! Here’s how to navigate the Las Vegas pool scene this summer.
pinterest.hed: The Hottest Pools in Las Vegas

items.caption: Begin somewhere on the quiet side, like **[Aria’s Liquid Pool & Lounge](http://www.arialasvegas.com/pools-spa/pools/liquid-day-club-lounge)**, which is shielded by tall acacia trees. Few swimmers are out before 10 a.m., so prepare for the long day ahead by requesting cold cucumber slices for your eyes (702-693-8300; cover from $10).

Next, make the (relatively) scenic stroll through the Daniel Libeskind–designed Crystals shopping center to **[The Cosmopolitan’s Marquee](http://www.cosmopolitanlasvegas.com/experience/nightclub.aspx)**, where even at noon there might be Victoria’s Secret Angels and Olympians (Michael Phelps!) dancing with hipsters beneath the lanterns (702-333-9000; cover Fri.–Sun., $20).
items.credit: Photo courtesy of The Cosmopolitan/Thomas Hart Shelby photography

items.caption: Nibble on lobster rolls or turkey BLTs and, once you tire of standing near the perfectly toned, seek solace at the **[Mandarin Oriental’s pool deck](http://www.mandarinoriental.com/lasvegas/hotel/)**, an unusually calm and quiet spot in this crazy city. On weekdays, $350 gets you a private cabana with champagne drinks, fruit, and even a PlayStation. You might also book a quick-fix Contour and Firm body treatment at the adjacent spa (702-590-8888).

Obviously, not all Vegas pools are fit for families, but there’s a place for everyone at Caesars Palace’s five-acre **[Garden of the Gods Pool Oasis](http://www.caesarspalace.com/things-to-do/garden-of-the-gods-pool-oasis.html)**, whose seven pools—one adults-only—have names and decor inspired by Roman gods (702-731-7280; cover, $10–$20).

Adults can venture on for Wolfgang Puck–­prepared pizzas at your next stop, **[Azure at the Palazzo](http://www.palazzo.com/Las-Vegas-Activities/Pools/Azure/)**, a pool that toes the line between relaxing and raucous—it was on Kim Kardashian’s bachelorette-party itinerary, for instance, but the gals were there for a ladies’ lunch (702-767-3724; cover, $20).

End the day with an only-in-Vegas-style party at **[Encore Beach Club](http://www.encorebeachclub.com/)**—the scene of Prince Harry and Ryan Lochte’s swim-off—and do prime people-watching amid three tiers of pools and two infinity hot tubs. Stay after dark and head over to Surrender, a nightclub bumping with beats by celebrity DJs like Skrillex (702-770-7300; cover, $30).




 




**More on [Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/cities/las-vegas)**




[10 Things Not to Do in Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/cities/las-vegas/Ten-Things-Not-to-Do-in-Las-Vegas)

pinterest.hed: Las Vegas for Business Travelers: Where to Eat, Stay and Play
pinterest.dek: Las Vegas is known as a city where visitors play hard, but that doesn't mean they can't work hard, too. Here are the best spots for business travelers—plus a few places to blow off steam.
pinterest.body:
[#image: /photos/546d2085cbbd2620680db5c2]||||||

Las Vegas may have a reputation as a sort of playground for adults, but it's long been a destination for business travelers, too—especially after its convention center opened in 1959. But just because you're there to work doesn't mean you can't find time to play, too. These are some of Vegas's best venues for client meetings and refined drinks—and, because it's Vegas, some spots where you can help a client blow off steam, too. 



##BREAKFAST WITH COLLEAGUES

__Veranda Cucina Italiana:__ The best power breakfast—and power-player spotting—in town *([Four Seasons Hotel Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/four-seasons--las-vegas))*.



##ESPRESSO

__Sambalatte Torrefazione:__ Excellent brews via Chemex, AeroPress, and Steampunk *(Monte Carlo Resort and Casino*).



##LUNCH WITH COLLEAGUES

__Estiatorio Milos__: Choose your own fish from the ice, to be prepared as you like *([Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/the-cosmopolitan-of-las-vegas); 702-698-7000; lunch prix fixe, $23).*



##LUNCH WITH PROSPECTIVE CLIENTS

__Country Club:__ The most private room for power brokers *([Wynn Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/wynn-and-encore-las-vegas); 702-770-3315; lunch entrées from $18).*


##DINNER SOLO

__Carson Kitchen:__ Sit at the butcher-block bar; have the fried chicken skins *(124 S. Sixth St.; 702-473-9523; entrées from $12).*



[#article: /articles/546d2323f3cd9c7947d5fcba]||||||








##DINNER WITH IMPORTANT CLIENTS

__Cut Las Vegas:__ Ask for the private room behind the bronze glass wall; order the wagyu short ribs *([Palazzo Resort Hotel Casino](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/the-palazzo);
702-607-6300; entrées from $38).*



##DIGNIFIED DRINKS

__Mandarin Bar:__ Reminiscent of 1930s Shanghai; its cocktails, like the Lychee Smash, have an Asian twist *([Mandarin Oriental, Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/mandarin-oriental--las-vegas)).*


##UNDIGNIFIED DRINKS

__[Hakkasan](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/las-vegas/hakkasan-inside-the-mgm-grand-hotel-and-casino):__ Allow resident DJ Steve Aoki to pour champagne over you—it’s the least respectable way to drink *(MGM Grand).*


##NEW TO THE NEIGHBORHOOD

The just-opened 1,600-room [SLS Las Vegas Hotel & Casino](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/las-vegas/sls-las-vegas-hotel-and-casino), the opulent reincarnation of the former Sahara, is redefining the social scene at the north end of the Strip with its three expansive nightclubs and restaurants by a who’s who of culinary players, like Bazaar Meat by José Andrés *(855-761-7757; doubles from $172).*



##SEE IT NOW

The best part about going to Vegas? It’s your big opportunity (or excuse) to indulge your guilty pleasure. This month, you can catch Shania Twain at [Caesars Palace](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/caesars-palace) (through December 13); Britney Spears at Planet Hollywood (through February 2015); and best of all, Tony Bennett and Lady Gaga at the Cosmopolitan on New Year’s Eve (good luck getting tickets). Don’t forget to bring a client so you can expense it.

miniGuides.hed: The Perfect Day in Las Vegas
miniGuides.dek: If you have just a few hours to spare head directly to the area surrounding Las Vegas’s CityCenter complex. Here you’ll find an outstanding array of public art, excellent shopping, and, at the Cosmopolitan Hotel, the strip’s most diverse dining options.
miniGuides.body:
[#image: /photos/54934a0f0f6c91ef1e756bd8]|||
The Crystals Shopping Mall in CityCenter
|||





##PLAY HERE
Grab a map and take a self-guided tour the CityCenter’s $40 million finer art collection, with pieces by renowned contemporary artists including Nancy Rubins, Frank Stella, and Maya Lin. Just don’t miss Akhob, an immersive installation by James Turrell, commissioned by Louis Vuitton and occupying a 1,200 square-foot space over the brand’s flagship store at the Crystals shopping complex. Viewing is by appointment only and limited to 6 people at a time--which keeps the experience intimate and personal. 

##SHOP HERE
Designed by the studios of starchitects Daniel Libeskind and Norman Rockwell, [The Shops at Crystals](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/las-vegas/the-shops-at-crystals-citycenter) brings together some of the biggest luxury brand names, including Prada, Gucci, and Hermès. There are also a number of restaurants, most notably outposts from Todd English and Wolfgang Puck. 



##EAT HERE 
[The Cosmopolitan](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/the-cosmopolitan-of-las-vegas), the luxury resort and casino that opened in 2010, lies just north of the CityCenter complex and is home to over a dozen restaurants, including Scott Conant’s Scarpetta and José Andrés’s Jaleo. But for a unique experience, book a dinner at [Rose. Rabbit. Lie.](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-02-10/rose-rabbit-lie-las-vegas-restaurant), a restaurant, nightclub, and cabaret all rolled into one. Order the Heavenly Eggs appetizer and the Airmail cocktail—just don’t bring the kids!
miniGuides.seoDescription: Conde Nast Traveler's guide to 3 Hours in Las Vegas reveals the top must-dos while you're in town and short on time.
miniGuides.socialDescription: Conde Nast Traveler's guide to 3 Hours in Vegas reveals the top must-dos while you're in town and short on time.

fields.title: crystals-shops-las-vegas.jpg
fields.credit: Photo courtesy Robert Harding World Imagery / Alamy

miniGuides.hed: The Perfect Weekend in Las Vegas
miniGuides.dek: Las Vegas can be a tough city to explore. There’s so much to do and see inside the various casino resorts on the roughly four-mile Las Vegas Strip as well as in Downtown Vegas and Off The Strip that you’ll always leave without seeing even half of what’s there. Getting around the city can also be difficult, especially on the weekends when everyone descends upon the strip. Here’s what you absolutely must see and do.
miniGuides.body:
[#image: /photos/549367170f6c91ef1e756def]|||
Drai's Beach Club
|||










##DAY 1








__STAY__

[The Vdara Hotel & Spa](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/las-vegas/vdara-hotel-and-spa): This all-suite hotel at CityCenter lacks a casino but does have a superb location in the middle of the Strip, making it easy to walk to neighboring casinos. Its ESPA at Vdara focuses on holistic and revitalizing treatments, nd for an extra $50, guests can skip the long check-in lines at arrival and get a curbside check-in via iPad instead, a convenience that’s well worth the money on crowded Fridays.


__EAT__  

[Giada's:](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/las-vegas/giada) On the second floor of [The Cromwell Hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/las-vegas/bound-at-the-cromwell-hotel) at the intersection of Las Vegas and Flamingo, Food Network chef Giada De Laurentiis’ first ever restaurant overlooks the frenetic pace of the Strip. Inside, the vibe is more laid-back California, with a few nods to her family’s movie-making legacy. Both her breakfast and dinner menus offer gluten-free and vegetarian options, making a meal here less gluttonous than others in town.


__DRINK__  

[The Chandelier Bar at The Cosmopolitan](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/las-vegas/the-chandelier-bar-at-the-cosmopolitan-las-vegas): There’s no better way to kick off your Vegas adventure than inside the glamorous three-story chandelier in the heart of The Cosmopolitan. Sip on specialty cocktails (like the Finishing School) or order old classics while you stare at the endless, glittering crystal strands. 


__PLAY__  

[Neon Museum](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/las-vegas/neon-museum): Visiting the two-acre “Boneyard” behind the Neon Museum is like taking a walk down Vegas’ own memory lane. In a town where restaurants, shows, and bars come and go, the Neon Museum is a memorial to what Vegas used to be (the main house of the museum is actually within the 60s-era La Concha Motel). More than 150 neon signs are available to view during a docent-guided tour. In the summer months, book your tour for early in the morning before the desert heat becomes unbearable.

__PARTY__


[XS](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/las-vegas/xs-nightclub): Encore Las Vegas’ indoor/outdoor nightclub has 95 VIP tables and 30 VIP cabanas outdoors. The signature drink is The Ono Cocktail, which is made with Charles Heidsick Champagne Charlie 1981 and Louis XII de Remy  Martin Black Pearl cognac and costs $10,000. There’s also has a solid line-up of resident EDM DJs such as Avicci, David Guetta, Deadmau5 and Zedd. 

[#image: /photos/549367150f6c91ef1e756de5]|||
Giada's at The Cromwell|||







##Day 2

__STAY__

[The Wynn Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/wynn-and-encore-las-vegas): The resort and its sister property, Encore, has perfected luxury in nearly every way, from the generously-sized rooms to several award-winning restaurants, high-end shopping (including the only Givenchy store in the U.S), a championship golf course, and stunning spa facilities. Its intense and wonderful Le Reve show features death-defying water acrobatics while its XS nightclub is one of the hottest spots on the strip.

__EAT__

[STRIPSTEAK Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/las-vegas/stripsteak-las-vegas): There are no shortages of steakhouses in Las Vegas, but Chef Michael Mina’s STRIPSTEAK at the [Mandalay Bay](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/las-vegas/mandalay-bay) sticks to the classics. The menu is well-rounded, with nine different Angus and Wagyu entrees, and several seafood selections, but don’t forget the side dishes like truffled mac n’ cheese and potato gratin. 



__DRINK__

[Sin City Brewery Co](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/las-vegas/sin-city-brewing-company).: Sin City Brewing Co. has three different locations on the Strip, each serving the company’s five signature beers--Amber, Light, IPA, Weisse and Stout--as well as seasonal selections. The brews are all produced locally in small batches in strict accordance with the Reinheitsgebot, the 1516 German beer purity law. 

__PLAY__

[The High Roller](http://cntraveler.com/activities/las-vegas/the-high-roller): At 550 feet, the world’s tallest observation wheel is open daily from 11:30am to 2am. It takes 30 minutes to complete a full revolution during which you get an eagle-eyed view of The Strip and beyond. Forty people can fit into a single observation pod, making them great for group occasions. Just remember that ticket prices increase after 7pm, when the LED lights on the pods are turned on and the views of the lit-up Strip are particularly spectacular.


__PARTY__

[Hakkasan](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/las-vegas/hakkasan): The Hakkasan restaurant occupies the first two floors of this five-story, Chinois-inspired 80,000-sq-ft. nightclub at the far end of the MGM Grand, but serious partiers should head up to the main room and mezzanine levels to catch resident superstar DJs like Calvin Harris, Steve Aoki, and Tiesto in action.  


[#image: /photos/5493671e75c4333528ffc888]|||
The High Roller.
|||










##Day 3

__STAY__

[The Linq Hotel & Casino](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/las-vegas/the-linq-hotel-and-casino): Located across from the extravagant Caesars Palace, The Linq Hotel offers a budget-friendly yet tech-savvy stay. Named for the adjacent shopping and entertainment promenade, the hotel has thoroughly modern rooms, complete with WiFi hotspots in every room. Its 3535 Bar features infusion cocktails as well as wines on tap and outlets next to the bar seats for charging your phone. Guests also get priority reservations to other restaurants and clubs on the promenade.


__EAT__

[Umami Burger](http://cnt.conde.io/restaurants/las-vegas/umami-burger): Now open at The SLS Las Vegas, this outpost of the Los Angeles burger chain has an outdoor patio/beer garden that faces out onto Las Vegas Boulevard. The menu is similar to other Umamis--there’s the bacon-loaded manly burger and the truffle burger--but this location also offers a Jose Andres Burger in honor of the chef, who has a restaurant next door. The burger has a pork and cured ham patty, piquillo pepper confit, caramelized onion, manchego cheese, and roasted garlic aioli. 

__DRINK__

[Bound at The Cromwell](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/las-vegas/bound-at-the-cromwell-hotel): World-renowned mixologist Salvatore Calabrese created the cocktail menu for his seductive Bound Lounge at The Cromwell Hotel. You can’t go wrong with a classic martini, Calabrese’s specialty, but there’s also the Cromwell Fizz, made with Macallan fine oak whiskey, lemon juice, and orange bitters topped with Moët & Chandon Impérial champagne.
	
__PLAY__

[Brooklyn Bowl](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/las-vegas/the-shops-at-crystals-citycenter): Just steps away from The High Roller Observation Wheel is Brooklyn Bowl.  Here you’ll find 32 lanes, an on-site Blue Ribbon serving fried chicken and milkshakes, five on-site bars, and live concerts.

__PARTY__


[Drai's](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/las-vegas/drai-s-las-vegas): During the day, the rooftop pool area of The Cromwell Hotel is actually a part of Drai’s Beach Club, with three pools, seven DJ tables, and 15 cabanas. At night, the beach club becomes a part of Drai’s Nightclub, a two-story indoor/outdoor dance party that’s the only nightclub in Las Vegas zoned for fireworks. 


[#image: /photos/549368ce75c4333528ffc8ab]|||
A room at The LINQ
|||
