fields.name: Juliana Shallcross
fields.shortBio: Juliana is a digital contributor to *Condé Nast Traveler*.
fields.bio: Juliana Shallcross was the managing editor of three daily travel sites-- [HotelChatter.com](http://hotelchatter.com/), [Jaunted.com](http://jaunted.com/) and [VegasChatter.com](http://vegaschatter.com/)--for over ten years. Now, she's keeping tabs on the ever-changing hotel landscape for *Condé Nast Traveler*. Aside from maintaing a healthy (most of the time) obsession with hotels, she's also chronicling cool places to take the kids at her own site, [TripsandGiggles.com](http://tripsandgiggles.com/). She's currently based in Los Angeles. Her favorite hotel amenities are fluffy pillows and free WiFi.

contributorsAuthor.name: Juliana Shallcross
contributorsAuthor.shortBio: Juliana is a digital contributor to *Condé Nast Traveler*.
contributorsAuthor.bio: Juliana Shallcross was the managing editor of three daily travel sites-- [HotelChatter.com](http://hotelchatter.com/), [Jaunted.com](http://jaunted.com/) and [VegasChatter.com](http://vegaschatter.com/)--for over ten years. Now, she's keeping tabs on the ever-changing hotel landscape for *Condé Nast Traveler*. Aside from maintaing a healthy (most of the time) obsession with hotels, she's also chronicling cool places to take the kids at her own site, [TripsandGiggles.com](http://tripsandgiggles.com/). She's currently based in Los Angeles. Her favorite hotel amenities are fluffy pillows and free WiFi.

contributorsAuthor.name: Rebecca Frisch
contributorsAuthor.bio: Rebecca Frisch toddled into Sin City at the age of two and grew up watching casinos rise, fall and rise again. Since she didn’t have the neck strength to be a showgirl, she traded dreams of headlines for bylines and discovered the pen is, in fact, mightier than the sequined headdress.

featuredPlays.name: Smith Center for the Performing Arts
featuredPlays.description: Until recently, most performing arts arrived in Las Vegas in the form of long-running extravaganzas. Enter the most hotly anticipated cultural venue in recent las Vegas history: a $450 million, breathtaking Art Deco center hosting everyone from the Israel Philharmonic, to Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, to the Cleveland Orchestra, and the Academy of St. Martin in the Fields, just to name a few.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: You'll find Broadway shows and world-class orchestras performing at this Art Deco-inspired center.

featuredPlays.name: Mob Museum
featuredPlays.description: The actual former federal courthouse where such landmark hearings as the 1950 Kefauver Hearings on Organized Crime were held is now a museum dedicated to the history of organized crime. Among its showpieces—a piece of the bullet-ridden wall from the St. Valentine's Day Massacre, interactive exhibits on wiretapping, and real weapons used by mob hit men.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: See Bugsy’s sunglasses, Gotti's favorite white suit and more at this museum for all things gangster.

featuredPlays.name: International Museum and Library of Conjuring Arts
featuredPlays.description: Strip fixture and world-renowned magician David Copperfield didn’t fritter his millions away on high living. Instead, he invested in memorabilia and ephemera from his forerunners, housing his extraordinary collection in a warehouse that forms part of his firm’s headquarters (this was once the Nevada Nuts & Bolts factory, where the Statue of Liberty was restored). Entering through what resembles a vintage menswear store via a secret door, it’s like American Horror Story: The Museum. Tiptoe gingerly past the automata staring at you, down aisle after aisle of tricks and traps from decades past. He has an impressive stash of Houdini’s illusions, including his Water Torture Cabinet and Metamorphosis Trunk as well as the woman-sawed-in-half gizmo that Orson Welles commissioned for Rita Hayworth. Though it’s not officially open to the public—it’s apparently restricted to fellow magicians and serious collectors —a connected concierge can probably wrangle a visit, given enough notice (and tips).
featuredPlays.shortDescription: David Copperfield's haul of magic memorabilia and ephemera is worth the trip to the outskirts of the city.

featuredPlays.name: Valley of Fire State Park

address.street: Exit 75 off Interstate 15 (55 miles northeast of Las Vegas)

featuredPlays.description: One of the great surprises of what seems like a barren, tumbleweed-strewn desert is this incredible region of beet-colored rock formations that offers some of Nevada's prettiest hiking. About an hour northeast of Las Vegas, the blank terrain suddenly gives way to a basin of looming red-and-white sandstone hills spreading out over more than 34,000 acres. Some of the 150-million-year-old formations look like beehives, another resembles an elephant. Plus, there are Native American petroglyphs from approximately a millennium ago.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: Take a break from the Strip and head here for some of the state's best—and most breathtaking—hiking.

featuredEats.name: Andrea's
featuredEats.description: The venue at Encore Las Vegas is named "Andrea's" by the casino owner Steve Wynn in a pretty tribute to his wife. At the helm of the cream-, cognac-, and gold-hued room dripping with Venetian glass teardrops is Chef Joseph Elevado, who returns to Vegas from L'Ermitage Beverly Hills. DJ Steve Angello (of Swedish House Mafia fame) directs the music for the restaurant, whose vast, eight-page menu of Asian food plays to a social, sharing crowd. There's lots of specialty sushi (Wagyu beef and lobster) on the menu, plus Dungeness crab fried rice, duck confit lo mein, and dozens of other elevated Asian share plates. For dessert: Since Andrea's has its own entrance into Surrender nightclub, you won't need to stand in line with other clubbers after your meal.
featuredEats.cuisine: Eclectic or Global, Japanese or Sushi
featuredEats.shortDescription: A social spot that starts with elevated Asian share plates like Dungeness crab fried rice and ends with entry to its own nightclub.

featuredEats.name: STRIPSTEAK Las Vegas
featuredEats.description: There are no shortages of steakhouses in Las Vegas but Chef Michael Mina’s STRIPSTEAK at the Mandalay Bay sticks to the classics. The menu is well-rounded, with nine different Angus and Wagyu entrees, and several seafood selections, but the side dishes like truffle mac n’ cheese and potato gratin can overpower everything else. Except dessert.
featuredEats.shortDescription: At Chef Michael Mina's steakhouse, Angus and Wagyu will keep you company, and the truffle mac n' cheese is an affair to remember.

featuredEats.name: Nove Italiano
featuredEats.description: Use the elevator ride up to the 51st floor of the Palms' Fantasy Tower to primp: Once the doors open, everyone in the sunken dining room will turn to see what you're wearing and whom you're with. But Nove—a venture from the N9NE Group (N9NE Steakhouse, Ghostbar)—has substance as well as style. Italian dishes such as the baked artichoke (stuffed with chopped artichoke hearts), shellfish spaghetti, and lobster, goat cheese, and arugula flatbread are well executed. Be prepared for the nightclub-like details, including loud music and gilt-framed video screens showing slides of Italian masters.
featuredEats.shortDescription: This Italian restaurant actually delivers the culinary goods amidst an ultra-hip scene.

featuredEats.name: Lotus of Siam
featuredEats.description: This restaurant doesn’t look like much from the outside: at a grungy strip mall in windswept Winchester, sandwiched between a wig shop and a bar with blacked-out windows. The décor isn't much, either, like a standard suburban Thai restaurant, with floral wallpaper and photos of past customers. The hint that Lotus of Siam might stand apart is the boldface names in those snaps, who have pilgrimaged here to sample the outstanding menu. Forget gluey pad thai or stringy green papaya salads—this is food cooked by, and for, expat Thais. James Beard nominee Saipin Chutima’s menu includes a standalone Northern Thai section, featuring Thum Ka Noon, a tangy jackfruit and ground pork mêlée (spice fiends rejoice: you can ask for amped-up hotness on most dishes). Don’t leave without ordering a side of Nam Prik Ong, or red chili dip—chunky and tangy like tomato relish, it’s served with crudités.
featuredEats.shortDescription: The best Thai in town, beloved by locals and Chef José Andrés alike, is in the unlikeliest of spots.

play.dek: The Netherlands-born, Vegas-based DJ tells us where to eat, drink, play, and relax in Sin City.
play.body:
[#image: /photos/54526e9c7a32829f354be9f4]||||||


There’s more to Las Vegas than gambling, and who better to recommend things to do in Sin City than Tiësto? The legendary DJ was born in the Netherlands, but has since adopted Las Vegas as his home. We recently caught up with the world-famous beats master at the [TomorrowWorld music festival](http://www.tomorrowworld.com/home) to get his take on the best things to do in Las Vegas.   

__Why Las Vegas?__

It’s one of the best cities in the world. Vegas, in a nutshell, is basically whatever you could possibly want in your life, *whenever* you want it. The people are happy, they’re there to have fun, there’s super service, the nightlife is great, and the restaurants!

__Where do you go for a night out?__ 

Well, if you’re with your girlfriend, you have to try this really great Italian spot on top of the Palms, called [NOVE](http://www.palms.com/fine-dining/nove-italiano). It has a spectacular view of the whole city. If you’re with your girl, that’s the place to go. 

__Where do you go for dinner with the guys?__

If you want to have a good time with the guys, I would say [STK](http://www.cosmopolitanlasvegas.com/taste/restaurant-collection/stk.aspx) at the Cosmopolitan. The food is delicious, the drinks are excellent, and there's a really, really attractive staff and clientele. 

__What’s your favorite place to perform?__

[Hakkasan](http://hakkasanlv.com/) at the MGM. When the developers of the venue were in the planning stages they came to me and said, “we want to build a club for you.” They wanted to know how to create a club that made every DJ feel comfortable playing there. And I told them what I thought: make a great DJ booth, bring the people close, make sure everyone has a good view. And they did an amazing job. I mean, it’s a big venue—6,000 people—and it still feels intimate. 

__Where do you go to be a spectator?__

I go to the [MGM Arena](http://www.mgmgrand.com/entertainment/grand-garden-arena.aspx) a lot—I saw the Mayweather fight there recently *[where Floyd Mayweather defeated Marcos Maidana in a unanimous decision on September 13th]*. He’s a fabulous defender and the biggest fights are always at the MGM. Also, I know it’s good to go out with the ladies to the [Britney Spears Show](http://www.mgmgrand.com/entertainment/grand-garden-arena.aspx)—they love it. 

__What exciting things are happening in Las Vegas right now?__

Downtown Las Vegas is like a whole new world. In the last few years it’s changed a lot. It’s like the Williamsburg, Brooklyn of Las Vegas—it’s more indie and alternative. There’s a great bar called [Commonwealth](http://commonwealthlv.com/) that’s representative of the scene. And a great restaurant called [Le Thai](http://www.yelp.com/biz/le-thai-las-vegas) right next door—it’s really authentic and really delicious. 

__Where are your favorite places to get a cocktail?__

There are a ton of great options. [The Mandarin Oriental:](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/mandarin-oriental--las-vegas) is quite expensive, but it’s a really classy place with great cocktails. The restaurant at Hakkasan also has amazing drinks—their signature cocktail is made with ginger and it has a very interesting, delicious taste. Also, there’s this spot at the Cosmopolitan called [The Chandelier](http://www.cosmopolitanlasvegas.com/experience/lounges-and-bars/chandelier.aspx) with this really special drink; it’s called The Verbena and it comes with a flower that you eat. It opens your taste buds and then you take a sip and the effect is wild. It’s a very crazy taste.

__What about spots for comfort food?__

There’s this place called the [Peppermill](www.peppermilllasvegas.com). They’ve got a really good breakfast. I always get eggs with sausage—well, maybe a little bit of bacon here and there.  

__Where do you have visitors stay?__
   
There’s a really nice part of the MGM that I’d absolutely recommend—I always have my friends and family stay there—called the [Skylofts](http://www.skyloftsmgmgrand.com/flash.html). They have great views of the strip. The food is good. The room is really nice; it’s modern, but warm. 

__How do you get away from the craziness?__

I like to go to Lake Mead. You drive twenty minutes to the south, rent a boat, and spend a day on the water. It’s chill and you won't really see too many people.  

__When you’re jetlagged and exhausted, where do you go to recharge?__

That’s easy. I go to the [Encore Spa at the Wynn](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/las-vegas/wynn-and-encore-las-vegas). They have this amazing hot stone massage—it totally gets me in the right frame of mind. And there’s so much else you can do there—there are a million great treatments.

play.dek: Bikinis! Bellinis! Kardashians! Here’s how to navigate the Las Vegas pool scene this summer.
play.hed: The Hottest Pools in Las Vegas

items.caption: Begin somewhere on the quiet side, like **[Aria’s Liquid Pool & Lounge](http://www.arialasvegas.com/pools-spa/pools/liquid-day-club-lounge)**, which is shielded by tall acacia trees. Few swimmers are out before 10 a.m., so prepare for the long day ahead by requesting cold cucumber slices for your eyes (702-693-8300; cover from $10).

Next, make the (relatively) scenic stroll through the Daniel Libeskind–designed Crystals shopping center to **[The Cosmopolitan’s Marquee](http://www.cosmopolitanlasvegas.com/experience/nightclub.aspx)**, where even at noon there might be Victoria’s Secret Angels and Olympians (Michael Phelps!) dancing with hipsters beneath the lanterns (702-333-9000; cover Fri.–Sun., $20).
items.credit: Photo courtesy of The Cosmopolitan/Thomas Hart Shelby photography

items.caption: Nibble on lobster rolls or turkey BLTs and, once you tire of standing near the perfectly toned, seek solace at the **[Mandarin Oriental’s pool deck](http://www.mandarinoriental.com/lasvegas/hotel/)**, an unusually calm and quiet spot in this crazy city. On weekdays, $350 gets you a private cabana with champagne drinks, fruit, and even a PlayStation. You might also book a quick-fix Contour and Firm body treatment at the adjacent spa (702-590-8888).

Obviously, not all Vegas pools are fit for families, but there’s a place for everyone at Caesars Palace’s five-acre **[Garden of the Gods Pool Oasis](http://www.caesarspalace.com/things-to-do/garden-of-the-gods-pool-oasis.html)**, whose seven pools—one adults-only—have names and decor inspired by Roman gods (702-731-7280; cover, $10–$20).

Adults can venture on for Wolfgang Puck–­prepared pizzas at your next stop, **[Azure at the Palazzo](http://www.palazzo.com/Las-Vegas-Activities/Pools/Azure/)**, a pool that toes the line between relaxing and raucous—it was on Kim Kardashian’s bachelorette-party itinerary, for instance, but the gals were there for a ladies’ lunch (702-767-3724; cover, $20).

End the day with an only-in-Vegas-style party at **[Encore Beach Club](http://www.encorebeachclub.com/)**—the scene of Prince Harry and Ryan Lochte’s swim-off—and do prime people-watching amid three tiers of pools and two infinity hot tubs. Stay after dark and head over to Surrender, a nightclub bumping with beats by celebrity DJs like Skrillex (702-770-7300; cover, $30).




 




**More on [Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/cities/las-vegas)**




[10 Things Not to Do in Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/cities/las-vegas/Ten-Things-Not-to-Do-in-Las-Vegas)

Vegas is supposed to have something for everyone. I was doubtful of the truth in that remark, but then, I found the [Neon Museum](http://www.neonmuseum.org/), a few miles north of the strip. You can barely peek through the fence at the wonders inside—if you want a look at the outrageous color and typography that is vintage Vegas neon, you’ll have to take a tour.



And it’s totally worth it. The peeling paint and broken light bulbs and sharp metal edges of the giant neon signs make for [amazing photos](http://www.nerdseyeview.com/blog/2009/10/21/in-the-neon-boneyard/). But the guides are great storytellers too. Under the hot Nevada sunshine (bring a hat, a bottle of water, and wear sunscreen), I heard tales of mobsters and musicians and life in a city without clocks. The crazy thing? I now have a reason to go back to Vegas. That's unexpected.

featuredShops.name: The Forum Shops at Caesars
featuredShops.description: Since a 2004 expansion, the Forum Shops at Caesars Palace are no longer a quick stop. Fashion addicts can spend a full day touring the 160 stores, including Valentino, Escada, Etro, Roberto Cavalli, Marc Jacobs, Jimmy Choo, Gucci, Pucci, Tod's, and Christian Lacroix. The downside is the confusing layout, with curving escalators weaving through the three-story atrium. Despite the high volume of shoppers, employees are pretty attentive. Of course, there's plenty for kids: Replicas of the Trevi and Triton Fountains and a pyrotechnic-heavy reenactment of the Fall of Atlantis are all part of the fun. The best place to eat at the Shops: Spago.
featuredShops.shortDescription: Your one stop for over 100 luxury brands, including Valentino, Gucci, Tod's, and Marc Jacobs.

featuredShops.name: Via Bellagio
featuredShops.description: The wonder of Via Bellagio lies not only in its architecture but also in its collection of high-end brand names: Armani, Hermès, Chanel, Gucci, Prada. Don't miss stores are Chanel and Dior. But no intimidating salespeople here: They're mostly helpful and inviting. Though it's part of Bellagio resort, Via Bellagio has its own valet parking just west of the Strip on Flamingo Road. Don't miss the stunning seasonal displays at The Conservatory, kept fresh by dozens of landscape artists; and increasingly sophisticated shows at the Bellagio Gallery of Fine Art.
featuredShops.shortDescription: Chanel and Dior are musts at this shopping center, designed to resemble a Milanese galleria.

featuredShops.name: Wynn Esplanade
featuredShops.description: There's not much difference between the Wynn's shopping strip and Via Bellagio. Both promenades have small boutiques with big names (here: Chanel, Oscar de la Renta, Dior, Cartier, Brioni, and Graff), though Wynn scored a win when it landed Manolo Blahnik. The Louis Vuitton store is also particularly good, with bar-like seating for checking out the bags. The Rolex store is the largest in North America, and has a fascinating "Rolex Experience" mini-museum in back, and Givenchy has just opened its first boutique in Las Vegas. There's also a Ferrari and Maserati dealership with about 40 cars on museum-like display and a $10 entry fee (so Vegas). If you already have wheels, use the hidden valet behind the hotel, just east of the Strip on Sands Boulevard (Spring Mountain Road). Look for a street sign that reads "Wynn South Gate," and you'll arrive directly at the Esplanade.
featuredShops.shortDescription: This shopping promenade has a mix of small boutiques and big name brands (e.g. Chanel, Cartier).

featuredShops.name: The Shoppes at the Palazzo
featuredShops.description: With high-fashion labels like Diane von Furstenberg and Christian Louboutin, the Palazzo's collection of shops doesn't seem to offer much of a departure from those at Wynn or Bellagio. But underneath the luxe sheen there's some character. At Double Helix, you can sip a glass of Duckhorn Merlot while owner Raymond Nisi, a former eye surgeon, gives helpful tasting notes on his not-so-common wines-by-the-glass. Vegas's master sommeliers have even been known to unwind here and pull a bottle or two from the adjoining retail shop. And don't miss a stop by Bauman's Rare Books, where friendly shopkeepers with MFAs in British history and creative writing display auction-quality vintage books, such as signed copies of Ken Kesey first editions and Frank Lloyd Wright sketches. The crowd favorite at the Palazzo is Barneys New York—the only place in Vegas where you can snatch up Frédéric Malle fragrances and Thom Browne suits. A tip: Use Barneys's exclusive valet tucked in a corner next to the Palazzo's main entrance on the Strip—it allows access to Barneys, the Palazzo Shoppes, and even the Grand Canal Shoppes at the Venetian next door.
featuredShops.shortDescription: A rare bookstore and wine bar give this high-end shopping center some much-needed character.
